p.text: The Supreme Court Rules commenced 1 July 1972. The Rules are reproduced as issued in the official Reprint No 7 of 8 May 2007. Since commencement, the Rules have been amended by the following:.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [SCR Pt 1 r 8] r 8 Interpretation

p.text: In these rules, unless the context or subject matter otherwise indicates or requires:
means the entity known as the Australian Securities Commission prior to 1 July 1998, and subsequently known as the Australian Securities and Investments Commission.
[def insrt Amendment 324: Gaz 152 of 23 October 1998 p 8427]
, when used in relation to costs assessed otherwise than by the Court, means assess in accordance with Part 11 of the Legal Profession Act 1987.
[def insrt Amendment 285: Gaz 83 of 24 June 1994 p 3198]
includes an acting associate Judge.

includes any artificial person.
means a determination made under section 180 of the Legal Profession Act 1987 as in force from time to time prior to 1 July 1994.
[def insrt Amendment 270: Gaz 19 of 26 February 1993 p 824 ; am Amendment 285: Gaz 83 of 24 June 1994 p 3198]
means a claim for relief under section 78 of the Act.
means:
in respect of a person:

the management of whose estate is, by the Protected Estates Act 1983 or by any order of the Court or the Guardianship Tribunal under that Act or under the Guardianship Act 1987 , committed to the Protective Commissioner,
of whose estate the Protective Commissioner has, in accordance with section 63 of the Protected Estates Act 1983, undertaken the management, or
in relation to whose property the Protective Commissioner is authorised as mentioned in section 66(1)(a) of that Act,
the Protective Commissioner,

in respect of a person of whose estate a manager has been appointed by order of the Court or the Guardianship Tribunal under section 22 of the Protected Estates Act 1983 or section 25M of the Guardianship Act 1987 — the manager appointed.
[def subst Amendment 319: Gaz 71 of 24 April 1998 p 2868 ; am Err 319: Gaz 73 of 1 May 1998 p 3093]
means a minor or an incompetent person.
[def subst Amendment 151: Gaz 103 of 29 June 1984 p 3386]
means any record of information, and includes:
anything on which there is writing,
anything on which there are marks, figures, symbols or perforations having a meaning for persons qualified to interpret them,
anything from which sounds, images or writings can be reproduced with or without the aid of anything else, or
a map, plan, drawing or photograph.
[def subst Amendment 303: Gaz 87 of 19 July 1996 p 4336]
[def rep Gaz 99 of 5 August 2005 r 3 and Sch 1 item [7], effective 15 August 2005]
means a person who has specialised knowledge based on the person's training, study or experience.
[def insrt Amendment 337: Gaz 9 of 28 January 2000 p 452]
means send a copy by facsimile transmission.
[def insrt Amendment 299: Gaz 26 of 1 March 1996 p 961]
means 100 words, five figures being counted as one word.

reference is made in the rules to the holder of an office in the Public Service or in the Australian Public Service; and
the name of the office is changed or the relevant function is assumed by the holder of another office,

[subr (2) insrt Amendment 293: Gaz 88 of 21 July 1995 p 3841]

Legislation cited in [SCR 1.8.1] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 rr 7.1, r 7.4.

The conduct of proceedings by corporations is dealt with in UCPR rr 7.1 and 7.2 . The definition of corporation in the present rule includes only artificial persons and is, accordingly, not wide enough to include partnerships or unincorporated associations that do not have a distinct legal personality. It follows that difficulties can arise in suing unincorporated associations. (As to these difficulties see Smith v Yarnold [1969] 2 NSWR 410; (1969) 90 WN (Pt 1) (NSW) 316 and Amey v Fifer [1971] 1 NSWLR 685 and cases there cited. The conduct of proceedings involving such an association is more fully discussed in the notes to UCPR r 7.4 . In many cases these problems may be overcome by an appropriate representative order under that rule.

The definitions of "disable" and "incompetent" persons centre on the capacity of the person to manage their affairs. This involves a qualitative assessment of the person's psychological and physical capacities. In that task some general guidelines exist. A person may be held to be incompetent by reason of being "incapable of managing his or her affairs" if it appears that:
there is a real risk of self-inflicted injury;
there is a real risk of injury as a result of the person's inability to take ordinary measures to attend to matters of physical well-being; or

there is a serious deterioration in the person's health or general well-being, that prevents them from dealing with ordinary routine affairs and creates a real risk of personal disadvantage or dissipation of assets: PY v RJS [1982] 2 NSWLR 700 at 702.

The definition of “document” in SCR 1.8 reflects the definition in the Dictionary to the Evidence Act 1995. The question of what falls within the definition of "document" arises principally in connection with discovery and subpoena issues: see [21.1.2] .
Legislation cited in [SCR 1.8.4] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Supreme Court (Corporations) Rules 1999 r 1.4.
(CTH) Corporations Act 2001 s 82A.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 35.3(1)(b).

Although the present definition, unlike that in Supreme Court (Corporations) Rules 1999 r 1.4 , does not expressly reflect the expanded definition in Corporations Act 2001 (Cth) s 82A it probably has a similar effect. The definition is inclusive and permits effect to be given to contemporary usage of the word “officer”. As such the definition includes not only persons who act as directors, managers and secretaries of the corporation (irrespective of their nominal title within the corporation) but also persons who exercise practical control over the affairs of the corporation: Foundation Enterprises Ltd v ML & C Heritage Pty Ltd (1998) 44 NSWLR 575; BC9804772 (“deemed director” able to verify pleadings for the purpose of UCPR r 35.3(1)(b) ). “Concerned in” or “taking part in the management of” in the definition of “officer” in s 9 of the previous Corporations Law was discussed in the judgment of Forge v Australian Securities and Investment Commission (2004) 52 ACSR 1; [2004] NSWCA 448; BC200408634 .
Legislation cited in [SCR 1.8.5A] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Supreme Court (Corporations) Rules 1999 r 7.10.

A court-appointed receiver is an officer of the court: see [26.3.10] . So is a tutor: Rhodes v Swithenbank (1889) 22 QBD 577 at 579 ; Watson v Watson (2001) 28 Fam LR 481; 166 FLR 229; [2001] FamCA 1470 . A court-appointed liquidator is also an officer of the court: Re ACN 003 671 387 and ACN 008 664 257 (2004) 49 ACSR 443; 22 ACLC 901; [2004] NSWSC 368; BC200402340 (applying Supreme Court (Corporations) Rules 1999 r 7.10 ). A person to whom proceedings have been referred under UCPR r 20.14 is not an officer of the court: see [20.13.5].

level.toc-caption: [SCR 1.8.6] References to the 1965 English rules of court

heading.title: References to the 1965 English rules of court

p.text: The sidenotes in the rules are references to the Rules of the Supreme Court (revised) 1965 (England) (“RSC (Rev) 1965”). The references are to the form of those Rules in 1969 at the time of the NSW Law Reform Commission Report No 7. The sidenotes have not been updated. The last English White Book containing those Rules is entitled "The Supreme Court Practice 1999". It has a Fourth Cumulative Supplement. Those Rules were replaced by the Civil Procedure Rules 1998 (UK).

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [SCR Pt 1 r 9] r 9 Seals

p.text: There shall be the seals mentioned in the first column in the table below, which shall be impressed seals and respectively shall have the wording mentioned in the second column of the table and shall be in the custody of the officer mentioned in the third column of the table.

row.entry: Supreme Court of New South Wales
Seal of the Court of Appeal
Supreme Court of New South Wales: Court of Appeal
Registrar of the Court of Appeal
Supreme Court of New South Wales: (name of the Division)

p.text: Each of the seals mentioned in subrule (1) shall have effect as the seal of the Court.

Except where the rules otherwise provide, but subject to subrule (4) , the seal of the Court of Appeal or the general seal of the Court shall be used for the purpose of proceedings in the Court of Appeal and the seal of each Division or the general seal of the Court shall be used for the purpose of proceedings in that Division.
[subr (3) am Amendment 61: Gaz 61 of 25 March 1977 p 1181]
A rubber stamp facsimile of any seal may be used instead of the seal for any purpose.
[subr (5) rep Amendment 85: Gaz 46 of 28 April 1978 p 1566]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [SCR Pt 1 r 9C] r 9C Filing prescribed bail forms by fax

leg:heading.title: Filing prescribed bail forms by fax

p.text: A document, which concerns an application relating to bail and the form of which is prescribed by the rules, shall be sufficiently filed if a copy of the document, produced in the Sydney registry by a facsimile transmission machine, is filed.
[r 9C insrt Amendment 280: Gaz 127 of 19 November 1993 p 6893]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [SCR Pt 1 r 11] r 11 Forms

p.text: Forms are prescribed in Schedule F .
A reference in any such form to a provision of these rules includes a reference to the corresponding provision (if any) of the Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005.
[subr (2) insrt Gaz 99 of 5 August 2005 r 3 and Sch 1 item [9], effective 15 August 2005]

If a form is approved under section 17 of the Civil Procedure Act 2005 in relation to the same matter as that for which a form is prescribed in Schedule F, the form to be used is the approved form and not the prescribed form.
[subr (3) insrt Gaz 99 of 5 August 2005 r 3 and Sch 1 item [9], effective 15 August 2005]
[r 11 subst Amendment 198: Gaz 140 of 4 September 1987 p 5067]

Although SCR Sch F contains a comprehensive set of forms designed to be used in conjunction with the Rules, there is in fact no express requirement that makes compliance with the prescribed forms mandatory: see further: see further CPA [s 17.5] . Many of the forms in SCR Sch F have been replaced by forms approved under the UCPR. Forms approved under the UCPR take precedence over forms prescribed under the SCR. Where no form is prescribed under the UCPR, the forms prescribed under the SCR should be adapted to accord with the format of documents under the UCPR.
Prescribed forms from Schedule F and approved forms under CPA are reproduced in Vol 3 behind the “Forms” guide card.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [SCR Pt 1 r 13] r 13 Procedure wanting or in doubt

p.text: Where a person desires to commence proceedings or take any step in any proceedings, and the manner or form of procedure is not prescribed by the Act or the rules or by or under any other Act or that person is in doubt as to the manner or form of procedure, the Court may, on application by that person, give directions.

ci:cite.ci:content: cf High Court Rules O 72 r 1(1)

p.text: Proceedings commenced in accordance with the directions of the Court shall be well commenced.
A step taken in accordance with the directions of the Court shall be regular and sufficient.
In respect of proceedings to be commenced for directions under subrule (1) , application may be made by summons in any Division.
[subr (4) insrt Amendment 3: Gaz 59 of 2 June 1972 p 2027]
Legislation cited in [SCR Pt 1.13.1] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 16.
(NSW) Supreme Court (Corporations) Rules 1999 r 1.8.

It sometimes occurs that there is no specific procedure, either in the rules or in the forms, that deals with the particular application or proceeding — notwithstanding that it is a matter that is clearly within the substantive jurisdiction of the court. In such a case the court (and the parties) must do the best that they can in the circumstances — which may involve devising "ad hoc" procedures: Browne v Cmr for Railways (1935) 36 SR (NSW) 21 at 29 per Jordan CJ (the judge must do "the best he can with the means he has available"); applying Edgar v Greenwood [1910] VLR 137 at 145 . This principle has been applied in many cases: see Hawke v Edwards (No 2) (1947) 48 SR (NSW) 234 at 235; 65 WN (NSW) 47; Hoban v Davey [1972] 1 NSWLR 59; Bogeta Pty Ltd v Wales [1977] 1 NSWLR 139 at 148. There is a similar power under CPA s 16 and r 1.8 of Supreme Court (Corporations) Rules 1999: see [15,035.5] .
